content.title: Madame Tussauds Hollywood

introduction.small: In the purest tradition of the wax museum, Madame Tussauds focuses on the most important Hollywood movie stars and artistic personalities.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Madame Tussauds Hollywood

paragraphs.text:
In London in 1835, Marie Tussaud came up with the idea of an exhibition of wax figures. It turned out to be a good idea, because, soon after, she opened wax museums in a dozen capitals throughout the world.

Take an hour to visit this playful museum, which, unlike its European counterparts, encourages visitors to take pictures with their favourite stars. To really get into the spirit of the photographic experience, take advantage of the costumes and props.

Everybody's here: Clint Eastwood, John Wayne, Captain Kirk and Lady Gaga. Madonna and Marilyn Monroe are larger than life, but President Obama is the favourite, hands down. The visit ends with a screening of a short 4D film, a futuristic technology that enriches images with startlingly sensory details.

Madame Tussauds Hollywood
6933 Hollywood Boulevard
Hollywood, CA 90028

+1 323 798 1670

www2.madametussauds.com/hollywood/en/

content.title: Universal Studios: the supreme reference

introduction.small: This phenomenal amusement park is in the top five of the most visited places in Los Angeles. Take a ride through the best-known scenes in American movies and TV series.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Universal Studios: the supreme reference

paragraphs.text:
Set aside a full day to enjoy this particularly entertaining place that opens the doors to the American film industry.

Built right next to the real studios which you can also explore by taking the famous Studio Tour this theme park can be visited on a mini-tram. The park is divided into two parts, allowing you to see and learn all about the scenery and special effects of Universal Studios' most famous movies. There are also rides and attractions. Visit the Lower Lot first. Watch out for the dinosaurs in Jurassic Park, before fighting the Transformers in 3D! Only adults are allowed on the insane roller coaster because it is so scary.

Then, go to the Upper Lot, which has some particularly hair-raising experiences involving the likes of King Kong, The Simpsons, Shrek, and the denizens of Waterworld.

Studios Universal
100 Universal City Plaza
Universal City
Los Angeles CA 91608

+1 800 864 8377

www.universalstudioshollywood.com

content.title: The Original Farmers Market: a gourmet getaway

introduction.small: Everybody in Los Angeles goes to 3rd Street and Fairfax Avenue for the trendiest food.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: The Original Farmers Market: a gourmet getaway

paragraphs.text:
See, feel, touch, and taste food in this airy bustling outdoor market. As far as the eye can see, fragrant food stalls and colourful pyramids of fruits and vegetables produced by small local farmers crowd one's vision.

Everyone comes here, from Texans to Australians to New Yorkers, attracted by the market's reputation and its global smorgasbord. Various artisans, bakers, and old Yiddish butchers sell alongside food trucks. Eat right there or order takeaway.

There's the famous Light My Fire, which specialises in spicy sauces, a peanut-butter maker, even a dog bakery... Depending on the day, orchestras enliven the market, which does not close its doors before 9:30 p.m. making it a great place to have dinner.

The Original Farmers Market
6333 W 3rd Street
Los Angeles, CA 90045

www.farmersmarketla.com

content.title: Sunset Ranch

introduction.small: Just a five-minute drive from downtown Hollywood, try this for a breath of fresh air and spectacular views of the city.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Sunset Ranch

paragraphs.text:
At this 50-horse ranch, mustangs are the dominant breed, but the skilled horseman will also recognise Appaloosas, the star horses of various equestrian disciplines, but also Pintos and peaceful Quarter Horses.

After a quick test, you will be directed to a suitable horse. The two-hour excursion in beautiful natural surroundings follows rocky trails along steep canyons and through richly wooded hills above the city.

An unforgettable experience, especially in the late afternoon when the sun lights up the purple foliage in Griffith Park.

Sunset Ranch
3400 North Beachwood Drive
Los Angeles, CA 90068

+1 323 469 5450

www.sunsetranchhollywood.com

content.title: Chateau Marmont: a cult address

introduction.small: A heritage building in Los Angeles, this imposing 1920s hotel boasts a life of stardom.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Chateau Marmont: a cult address

paragraphs.text:
With its contagious charm, the Chateau Marmont has been the scene of much merriment and tragedy, all of which is recorded in one of the most star-studded guestbooks in America.

The ultimate is to spend the night in one of the garden cottages next to the pool, some of which are reserved year-round by a who's who of cinema. Don't think, though, that you can just roar up to them on your motorcycle, like Led Zeppelin did. While the stunt impressed guests, it wreaked havoc in the lobby.

James Dean tried to climb the facade and Jim Morrison jumped off the roof, but you, however, can still find plenty of other less 'adventurous' things to do. Like meet at the famous hotel bar for a drink or dinner. With its elegant and festive atmosphere, and its bevy of Hollywood stars, reservations are, of course, strongly recommended.

Chateau Marmont
8221 Sunset Boulevard
Los Angeles, CA 90046

+1 323 656 1010

www.chateaumarmont.com

Rooms: from 395 USD

content.title: Ace Hotel Downtown: nostalgia for the past

introduction.small: This arty hotel is set up in a 1920s former cinema complex, once owned by United Artists.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Ace Hotel Downtown: nostalgia for the past

paragraphs.text:
Located in a vibrant neighbourhood, this historic place does not lack for personality. Though the ghost of Mary Pickford remains attached to the very decadent Gothic theatre right next to the hotel, the former picture palace now presents alternative theatre groups.

The Ace is distinguished by its sleek industrial interior: polished concrete, glass, and stainless-steel counterbalance the building's Art Deco shell. This loft-style hotel, with exposed beams punctuating the space, has a cool 1970s vibe.

There's even a jam room equipped with acoustic guitars and a turntable for budding rock stars. The elevator takes you to the rooftop with its small pool and bar. A great place for a party, the Ace attracts a trendy 30-something clientele that is cheerful and boisterous.

Ace Hotel Downtown
929 South Broadway
Los Angeles, CA 90015

+1 213 623 3233

https://www.acehotel.com/losangeles/

Rooms: from 170 USD

content.title: Balboa Park: a maze of nature and flowers

introduction.small: A five-hectare park pays tribute to the conquistador, Vasco Núñez de Balboa, the first European to discover the Pacific in 1513.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Balboa Park: a maze of nature and flowers

paragraphs.text:
Among the glorious facets of this park is the Panama-California exhibition, celebrating the inauguration of the Panama Canal the Port of San Diego is one of the major stops on the route. Gigantic haciendas in the popular Spanish Revival style were erected for the occasion.

Explore this majestic site and quiet ode to nature on foot, by tram, or on bike. Don't miss the tropical greenhouse, the remarkable orchid nursery and the roses, the cacti and the Japanese garden. You will also find a dozen museums, including one dedicated to aviation, as well as theatres, restaurants, and the San Diego Zoo with its 4,000 animals.

Managed by a foundation that works to protect endangered species, the zoo is a rare experience for visitors, who find themselves in the presence of white rhinos and pandas.

Balboa Park
San Diego, CA 92109

+1 619 239 0512

https://www.balboapark.org

content.title: Newport Beach: whale watching less than an hour out of L.A.

introduction.small: Newport Beach is a pleasant seaside resort in Orange County, from where you can board the ferry to Catalina Island, a beautiful exotic gem floating on the ocean.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Newport Beach: whale watching less than an hour out of L.A.

paragraphs.text:
This famous surf spot has a pleasant pedestrian promenade on the beach. In the Balboa neighbourhood, the bulk of the tourism trade is in whale watching.

So, embark on a great adventure in search of marine life and these immense mammals, which are considered to be very curious. For two exciting hours, the crew will deliver fascinating details about the habits of these intelligent animals, which have been the subject of many scientific studies did you know that whales are one of only three species, alongside humans and Balinese monkeys, able to learn and recall a melody.

Depending on the season, you will see giant blue whales, which migrate in summer and autumn, as well as sharp-nosed fin whales, which are fond of cruising in the calm summer waters of the Gulf.

Newport Landing Whale Watching
309 Palm St #A
Newport Beach, CA 92661

+1 949 675 0551

www.newportwhales.com

content.title: Disneyland: Mickey's enchanted kingdom

introduction.small: A holiday destination in its own right, the first Disneyland park, fully imagined and designed by the great Walt himself, opened in July 1955.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Disneyland: Mickey's enchanted kingdom

paragraphs.text:
Since opening, 650 million visitors have gone through the gates of the most famous amusement park in the world. Fairy lights, fantastic shows, spectacular parades, fireworks: welcome to the enchanted world of Mickey and Minnie.

With a Fast Pass in your pocket, you don't have to queue. Spend the time you save by going on all the rides. Main Street leads to the Emporium, a Victorian bazaar of Arabian trinkets and all kinds of souvenirs.

Among the park's highlights are Fantasyland and the iconic Sleeping Beauty's Castle, on the park's logo, a ride that introduces you to all the Disney characters and their charming houses. And don't forget Tomorrowland, a journey into the future as imagined in the 1950s, and Frontierland, dedicated to the Old West.

Disneyland
1313 Disneyland Drive
Anaheim, CA 92802

+1 714 781 4636

https://disneyland.disney.go.com

content.title: The Elan Hotel: deliciously nostalgic

introduction.small: With its vintage motel look suggestive of the last survivor of the 1970s, the Elan would fit right in on an Eagles' album cover.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: The Elan Hotel: deliciously nostalgic

paragraphs.text:
Tourists never fail to gaze in wonder at this modest, seemingly obsolete building, which goes totally against the grain of its luxurious neighbours. A kilometre and a half from the famous Beverly Center and Farmers Market, the Elan is in a trendy stronghold.

Its very sharp contemporary design combines with an eco-friendly policy highly prized by the bourgeois-bohemian circuit. The Elan Hotel is also the headquarters of an enlightened generation of architects, artists, and aesthetes of all nationalities who appreciate features like bamboo flooring and organic food.

The 49 tastefully furnished rooms and suites provide an uncluttered Zen atmosphere of comfort and ecologically sound natural-fibre bedding. Special wine-tastings are organised several times a week at which an oenologist will introduce you to regional vineyards and their best wines!

The Elan Hotel
8435 Beverly Boulevard
Los Angeles, CA 90048

+1 323 658 6663

https://www.elanhotel.com

Rooms: from 206 USD

content.title: Downtown: the modern heart of Los Angeles

introduction.small: More than a business district, Downtown is the very definition of the urban epicentre, housing the government of Los Angeles County and most institutions.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Downtown: the modern heart of Los Angeles

paragraphs.text:
The Downtown's sulphurous past has gradually died down, ushering in an era of renewal. The rather successful compromise between residential buildings, office towers, and entertainment venues has made a home for a mosaic of cultures and mestizo populations.

Downtown is proud of its Latino roots, which are remarkably preserved on Olvera Street. This is where Spanish missionaries built the original town, Pueblo, in 1781. This futuristic city, designed by top contemporary architects, is full of art galleries, concert halls, bars, and shops.

You will also find Little Tokyo, L.A. Live, the Fashion District, and Chinatown not to mention the Staples Center, whose inauguration in 1999 was a sign of the powerful renaissance experienced in this part of the city.

content.title: Getty Center: a concentration of culture

introduction.small: In the Brentwood hills, one of the largest cultural complexes in the world can be seen and admired for kilometres around.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Getty Center: a concentration of culture

paragraphs.text:
Inaugurated 20 years after the death of oil tycoon J. Paul Getty, this museum is the work of architect Richard Meier.

Anchored to an anti-seismic foundation, the Getty Center is an innovative cultural and scientific campus, and the home of incredible art collections belonging to the J. Paul Getty Museum. With an annual budget of 100 million USD, the Getty Center has an aggressive acquisitions policy. Ensconced in 45 hectares of landscaped gardens, five pavilions bathed in natural light hold a remarkable number of European artworks.

Besides sculptures and paintings from the classical period, the museum has a multitude of drawings and manuscripts, decorative objects and ceramics. Out of respect for the patron's wishes, the Getty Center collection does not include any 20th- and 21st-century art, except for photography and temporary exhibitions.

Getty Center
1200 Getty Center Drive
Los Angeles, CA 90049

+1 310 440 7300

www.getty.edu/visit/center

content.title: Venice Beach: L.A. hipster spirit

introduction.small: America's Venice was born of a tobacco baron's whim. In 1905, gondolas were imported from Italy for the hard-fought-for canals that had been dug out of wetlands.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Venice Beach: L.A. hipster spirit

paragraphs.text:
The victim of random stock market crashes, the Venice Beach neighbourhood suffered many setbacks before the construction, in the 1970s, of a wide bike path along the beach.

This turned Venice Beach into a tourist haven, especially for hippies and the physically fit: the waterfront is a never-ending parade of bodybuilders. People come here to browse in the beach market, see street performances, get a tattoo, or have a drink in one of the many bars. On the other side of the bay, be on the lookout for a string of unusual, small houses: their construction a happy union of metal, wood, and glass was inspired by architect Frank Lloyd Wright's environmental philosophy.

And if you feel like rollerblading, this is the place to do it. Surrounded by beginners and experienced bladers, you will get the feel for Venice as the world capital of sport on wheels. And the heart of the American way of life.

content.title: Si Laa Thai: the Kingdom of Siam opens its doors

introduction.small: This Asian restaurant is acclaimed for the beautifully fragrant subtleties of its menu.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Si Laa Thai: the Kingdom of Siam opens its doors

paragraphs.text:
With its cosy, pretty lights, white tablecloths, and delicate floral compositions, the serene atmosphere is very conducive to friendly dinners. The menu stays the course with exotic traditional Thai flavours.

The service is impeccable and attentive. The wait staff offers suggestions and any advice you might need. This refined restaurant, worthy of Bangkok itself, has managed to forge a solid reputation in this hamburger-lover's paradise.

Ideally accompanied by a glass of Californian merlot or a finely foamed Singha beer, marinated chicken with cashew nuts, short ribs of beef braised in green coconut served with sugar snap peas or Asian eggplant sautéed with garlic, Thai basil, bell peppers and jalapeño charm the palate. For a change of pace, lovers of spicy food will be delighted with the red curry or the Pad Thai.

Si Laa Thaï
1128 South Robertson Boulevard
Los Angeles, CA 90035

+1 310 858 7738

www.silaathai.com

Menu: around 30 USD

content.title: The Fountain Coffee Shop: lunch at a palace hotel

introduction.small: A jet-set favourite, nothing is more stylish than this coffee shop hidden in the basement of the Beverly Hills Hotel.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: The Fountain Coffee Shop: lunch at a palace hotel

paragraphs.text:
Suffice it to say that you have never really experienced L.A. until you try this West Coast establishment. Come into this palace hotel bar and sit down at the counter in the shade of exotic banana trees.

Before your eyes, the chef cooks to order whatever the customer desires. The brunch is remarkable, upstaged only by the ancient beverage fountain, a gleaming chrome masterpiece dating from the 1950s. Besides exquisite coffee liqueurs, it delivers malts, shakes, and fresh fruit and vegetable juices to start the day auspiciously.

These energising drinks go with a selection of omelettes, fruit salad, plus all kinds of crepes, croissants, pastries, and French toast in a large traditional tea room.

The Fountain Coffee Shop
Beverley Hills Hotel
9641 Sunset Boulevard
Beverly Hills, CA 90210

+1 310 276 2251

www.dorchestercollection.com/en/los-angeles/the-beverly-hills-hotel/restaurant-bars/

Menu: around 35 USD

content.title: Viceroy Santa Monica: an institution

introduction.small: This rather dull-looking building is located in a maze of greenery and flowers and just happens to be the most fashionable boutique hotel in Santa Monica.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Viceroy Santa Monica: an institution

paragraphs.text:
Its chic, classic atmosphere has many seductive elements, not to mention its ideal location for exploring the small, lively streets of this charming neighbourhood. Upon arrival, you will be greeted with a glass of chilled champagne.

Book your room on the eighth floor. These rooms, with living area, have breath-taking views of the skyline and the blue Pacific Ocean. Comfortable deckchairs await you poolside for a tanning session.

The clientele is very international, with the majority coming from the ranks of magazine photographers and movie producers. Note that the restaurant menu is organic. And finally, to top it all off, note, too, its extreme proximity to the beach: all you need do is cross Ocean Avenue to go for a swim in the Pacific.

Viceroy Santa Monica
1819 Ocean Avenue
Santa Monica
Los Angeles, CA 90401

+1 310 260 7500

www.viceroyhotelsandresorts.com/en/santamonica

Rooms: from 367 USD

content.title: Walk of Fame: boulevard of the stars

introduction.small: The most famous sidewalk in Hollywood recites the names of celebrities in the film and entertainment industries, as honoured by the Los Angeles Chamber of Commerce.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Walk of Fame: boulevard of the stars

paragraphs.text:
The Hollywood Walk of Fame, which is over a kilometre long, originally had 2,500 blank stars awaiting attribution. Now, nearly 2,600 of them have names attached.

At the induction ceremony, after a donation of 30,000 USD to the Hollywood Historic Trust Association (which manages maintenance), each new honouree generally, someone whose name is synonymous with talent and glamour is given a granite slab with its famous five-pointed star. A brass emblem indicates one of the five award categories: music, theatre, film, radio, or television.

Tip: the international stars are closer to Grauman's Chinese Theater (now known as the TCL Chinese Theater). Curiously, to this day, some great artists still do not have a star; so don't look for Leonardo DiCaprio, Robert Redford, or Madonna. Others, however, have managed to obtain several. On 12 November 2015, Harry Potter himself, Daniel Radcliffe, joined this illustrious constellation.

Walk of Fame
Hollywood Boulevard
Los Angeles, CA 90028

+1 214 434 9614

www.walkoffame.com

content.title: Hollywood's secret stairs: off the beaten track

introduction.small: Only true insiders know about this very original walking tour, which includes 40 staircases, thousands of steps and tens of kilometres… An ingenious fitness program during your holiday.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Hollywood's secret stairs: off the beaten track

paragraphs.text:
Hidden from view, these pedestrian stairways and bridges have connected certain hills of Los Angeles since the days before cars existed. One of them starts at Robinson Street. Seven hundred steps await those who make the climb up to Silver Lake, which entered cinematic history with The Music Box, a Laurel and Hardy film that won an Oscar in 1932.

Towards the Pacific Palisades, there is another walking tour of invigorating height that offers great views of the ocean. Walk until you reach rescue station # 2 on the pedestrian path that goes over the Pacific Coast Highway.

It takes 508 stairs to do the whole circuit from Castelmare Drive to Rosetano Road via Revello Drive. Take a picture of the extraordinary Getty Villa, an architectural symbol of the excesses of Hollywood's golden years.

content.title: Santa Monica Bay: one-on-one with the ocean

introduction.small: The Californian beach in all its splendour and vastness, with muscular surfers and lifeguards, and spectacular sunsets.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Santa Monica Bay: one-on-one with the ocean

paragraphs.text:
This idyllic setting is such a favourite TV and film location that you feel like you've already been here, even though you may be visiting for the first time. Santa Monica had starring roles in Forrest Gump, Rocky III, The Sting, and Iron Man.

The Harley-Davidsons of the world make their pilgrimages here, as the Santa Monica Pier is the last stop on the legendary Route 66, America's most famous transcontinental route, and a thoroughfare for early settlers an eternity ago. Stroll along Main Street and the Third Street Promenade with the joggers and rollerbladers. The streets are lined with cinemas, shops, and bars.

There is an amusement park at the end of the pier with a roller coaster and a 1920s merry-go-round. A few steps further, and you will find yourself sitting on the terrace of an old pub that is popular with fishermen. You are now at the end of the world.

content.title: Paradise Cove Beach Cafe: a Malibu must

introduction.small: Fine dining on the sands of the Pacific's most famous beach.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Paradise Cove Beach Cafe: a Malibu must

paragraphs.text:
The happy idleness of sea air, light, and waves are presented to you on a platter. With its colourful cocktails served in a watermelon and its tables anchored in the sand, this beach café operates with casual simplicity.

The rustic 1970s wood furniture traverses the ages. Known for its good food and generous servings, the restaurant always has a long wait. Keep your eye on the famous red lobster, a little gadget that flashes when your table is ready.

No surprises on the summer menu: huge fresh salads, seafood platters, fried scampi, penne with crab. After dinner, lounge on deckchairs until the sun disappears into the waves. Perfectly romantic.

Paradise Cove Beach Cafe
28128 Pacific Coast Highway
Malibu, CA 90265

+1 310 457 2503

www.paradisecovemalibu.com

Menu: around 42 USD

content.title: Rodeo Drive: Beverly Hills' shopping paradise

introduction.small: It's hard to imagine that this chic avenue was once an ordinary, dusty road leading to the Rodeo de las Aguas ranch.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Rodeo Drive: Beverly Hills' shopping paradise

paragraphs.text:
After a serious revamp in the 1970s, this Beverly Hills street became world famous for its concentration of prestigious brands.

This is, after all, where actress Julia Roberts went shopping in Pretty Woman. The glittering shop windows of luxury houses like Dior, Chanel, Tiffany, Vuitton, Armani, Cartier, and many others are all here, a universe inaccessible to ordinary mortals. Chauffeur-driven limousines silently and continuously discharge ladies in stilettos and eccentric millionaires onto the sidewalk. Don't miss the immaculate architecture of the facades, majestic palm trees waving against a turquoise sky, and the occasional murmur of a fountain.

Do not expect to come across any celebrities, though, as they tend to use the private entrances to these legendary boutiques.

content.title: Hotel Palomar: a boutique hotel in the heart of Beverly Hills

introduction.small: A guaranteed unforgettable stay, close to Westwood Village.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Hotel Palomar: a boutique hotel in the heart of Beverly Hills

paragraphs.text:
The Palomar, which is popular with the fashion and film worlds, has a certain idea of luxury and hospitality that fits perfectly with multi-starred ratings. Very elegant, the lobby, with its high ceiling, fireplace and plush sofas, sets the tone.

There is the same concern for perfection in the rooms, which are quiet, intimate, and relaxing. The suite on the 18th floor even has a private spa. Precious linens, stylish drapes, and artwork complement the iconic contemporary-design furniture.

The Palomar restaurant is one of the best in the city. Its menu is composed of original, high-quality organic ingredients in true Californian style.

Hotel Palomar
10740 Wilshire Blvd
Los Angeles, CA 90024

+1 310 475 8711

www.hotelpalomar-beverlyhills.com

Rooms: from 206 USD

content.title: Providence: shellfish and more

introduction.small: This Melrose Avenue institution is run by a rising star, chef Michael Cimarusti.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Providence: shellfish and more

paragraphs.text:
Having cut his teeth at L'Arpège and La Marée in Paris, and at Spago in Beverly Hills, chef Michael Cimarusti has acquired all the technique and vision to create a sublime seafood menu. The spices may come from the five continents, but the fish and seafood platters are local, and of a rare quality: Arctic char, Kumamoto oysters from Washington State, wild Maine lobster and halibut.

Chef Cimarusti brings together a quest for perfection and outstanding creativity in his delectable and finely executed dishes. Three tasting menus shed light on the house specialities. The wine list is without reproach, intelligently offering nearly 30 wines by the glass. The decor is modern, except for the fishing nets on the walls a knowing nod to the restaurant's maritime orientation.

Providence
5955 Melrose Avenue
Los Angeles, CA 90038

+1 323 460 4170

www.providencela.com

Menu: around 80 USD

content.title: Staples Center: the temple of American basketball

introduction.small: An iconic address in downtown Los Angeles, this multipurpose hall is a paradise for sport and prestige events.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Staples Center: the temple of American basketball

paragraphs.text:
Have a look at the programme of its home teams and book your tickets for the season-opener well in advance. The stadium goes electric when home teams the Lakers, Clippers, Sparks, and Kings hit the spotlight, creating a phenomenal atmosphere.

An unforgettable experience to share with 20,000 spectators, although, curiously, sports comprise only half of the 250 annual events.

Staples was Michael Jackson's favourite rehearsal space it was featured in Jackson's last tour and film This is It. Staples' eclectic programming goes from Lady Gaga and Justin Bieber to Mötley Crüe. This is also where the Grammy Awards take place, as well as Disney on Ice and champion WBC boxing matches

Staples Center
1111 South Figueroa Street
Los Angeles, CA 90015

+1 213 742 7100

www.staplescenter.com

content.title: The Griffith Park Observatory brings you closer to the stars

introduction.small: A haven of green, this huge urban park is popular for its hills, canyons, forests, and numerous hiking trails.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: The Griffith Park Observatory brings you closer to the stars

paragraphs.text:
When Welsh immigrant Griffith Jenkins Griffith died, he gave his land to the city. The will specified that the land be used for leisure and relaxation. Built in 1935, the Observatory is a mix of Art Deco and Egyptian styles. Besides an exceptional view of the stars, it offers a panoramic view of the city. Its very educational approach to the cosmos is remarkable. The Observatory organises scientific exhibitions and operates the popular planetarium. Nearly 70 million people have visited the Observatory since its reopening in 2006. This celebrated building has been in a number of films, from Rebel Without a Cause to Charlie's Angels and Yes Man. On the ground floor is the astronomy museum, whose central piece is a copy of Foucault's Pendulum, an experimental device designed to demonstrate the rotation of the earth.

Griffith Observatory
2800 East Observatory Road
Los Angeles, CA 90027

+1 213 473 0800

www.griffithobservatory.org

content.title: Los Angeles County Museum of Art: a fascinating retrospective

introduction.small: In the Miracle Mile district, this was once part of the Museum of Science, History, and Art before becoming a separate institution.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Los Angeles County Museum of Art: a fascinating retrospective

paragraphs.text:
In its modern shell of stone and glass, LACMA is an encyclopaedic museum covering art from five continents. Each year, the most important museum of the American West receives a million visitors, all coming to admire the 150,000 works scattered in seven pavilions.

Given the size of the collection, you should visit it level by level so as not to miss the essentials. The Ahmanson Building alone offers remarkable diversity. Art of the Pacific is at level 1. Level 2 brings together major artists of the 20th century, including Picasso, Magritte, and Matisse. Level 3 is reserved for Impressionists, like Renoir, Van Gogh, and Cézanne, as well as the Italian Renaissance, with a few Venetian paintings by Titian. On Level 4, there are ancient coins from India and Southeast Asia.

Egyptian art and Japanese art, meanwhile, are on two separate floors in the Hammer Building.

Los Angeles County Museum of Art
5905 Wilshire Boulevard
Los Angeles, CA 90036

+1 323 857 6000

www.lacma.org

content.title: Magic Castle: for the family

introduction.small: Just steps from Hollywood Boulevard, this castle is known for its friendly atmosphere. It regularly receives awards in travel guides for its welcoming staff and premises.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Magic Castle: for the family

paragraphs.text:
As soon as you step through the front door, the staff is there to make your stay as pleasant as possible. There is around-the-clock room service, self-service snacks and sodas, and advice for trips and sightseeing in town.

Particularly spacious and bright, the rooms at Magic Castle offer modern comfort. For groups of six people or more, you have the choice of several suites with very generous proportions.

These small apartments include living room, one or two bedrooms and an open kitchen overlooking the gardens and indoor pool. The pool is heated, open day and night, and very popular with children. If you prefer quiet, ask for a room at the back.

Magic Castle
7025 Franklin Avenue
Hollywood
Los Angeles, CA 90028

+1 323 851 3313

www.magiccastle.com

Rooms: from 269 USD

content.title: Sunset Tower: a legacy of the 1930s

introduction.small: Emblematic and monumental, this Art Deco hotel is a hymn to the movies… and popular with Hollywood stars.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Sunset Tower: a legacy of the 1930s

paragraphs.text:
Many prestigious people have stayed at the Sunset Tower, including Howard Hughes, Marilyn Monroe, Errol Flynn, Elizabeth Taylor, and even Bugsy Siegel, the mafia don who created the city of Las Vegas. To attract a cosmopolitan clientele, the Sunset Tower proprietors have redesigned every centimetre of this historical building, for the ultimate in comfort, design, and technology. The hotel rooms and valuable furniture are enveloped in a soft, soothing atmosphere.

The upper floors are reserved for panoramic suites, a spectacular rooftop penthouse, and a duplex with several rooms, large bay windows, and terraces. For a drink or a meal with friends, the Tower Bar on the ground floor is very appealing.

Its cosy wood panelling and fireplace are ideal for a romantic dinner. The menu draws inspiration from French bistros and the cuisine of northern Italy.

Sunset Tower
8358 West Sunset Boulevard
West Hollywood, CA 90069

+1 323 654 7100

www.sunsettowerhotel.com

Rooms: from 395 USD

content.title: The Ivy: the place to see and be seen

introduction.small: Be sure to dine in the garden of this English cottage, which is overgrown with climbing roses and ivy.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: The Ivy: the place to see and be seen

paragraphs.text:
Brunch at the Ivy ranks among the best in the city. In the evening, diners wait for their table reservations with free drink in hand the Ivy is always packed. The patio is delightfully romantic, though abutting a busy street.

Clubbers, starlets, and fashion people put on a great show, and the organic Californian cuisine is light and refreshing. The salads are rather sumptuous: the Caesar is a good bet.

Because of the generally warm weather, there are few classically sauced dishes; rather, there are things that come off the grill, such as organic chicken. The seafood ranges from fish and squid to crabs and lobsters, the last of which can be seen in the tanks. If you like pizza, order the fresh lobster pizza, a house specialty. And, for dessert, the lukewarm apple and blackberry crumble is a real treat.

The Ivy
113 North Robertson Boulevard
Los Angeles, CA 90048

+1 310 274 8303

www.theivyrestaurants.com

Menu: around 45 USD

content.title: Spago: excellent flavours

introduction.small: A Michelin two-starred gastronomic restaurant, deserving of its place on the podium.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Spago: excellent flavours

paragraphs.text:
The signature restaurant of the iconic Wolfgang Puck is an address to take very seriously. He has racked up many awards for his cuisine, wine list, and service, all of which are impeccable. You will inevitably dine in the company of an international clientele, because this is one of the most famous restaurants in the world. The elegant setting integrates a huge glassed-in kitchen. On the menu, the very fashionable fusion cuisine is revisited with subtlety. Simple and at the same time unique, it consists of whatever is fresh at the market, the fishmonger's or any of several nearby farms, yielding the most sensational savoury discoveries.

The grilled prime “cote de boeuf” served with pommes aligot, creamy parmesan polenta and pasta with white truffles are classics, while some dishes borrow from experimental molecular cuisine. For within these walls, gastronomy is always an adventure.
